data.text: Contents
Introduction

Patient health records are a valuable source of information underpinning the delivery of high quality, evidence based healthcare. An effective health records system ensures clinical information is properly managed and available whenever and wherever there is a justified need for that information.
Where paper case notes exist, timely and accurate case note volume tracking will have a positive impact on patient care that will ensure:
A contemporaneous account of care is available to inform clinical decision making;
Procedures are not cancelled because case notes are not available;
Outpatient appointments are not cancelled because case notes are not available;
Fewer complaints are received regarding non-availability of case notes, both by patients and clinicians;
Fewer administrative resources are required to search for case notes leading to better operational efficiency, which could result in savings that could be put towards clinical purposes.

Health records management including case note volume tracking is the responsibility of everyone who handles case notes, irrespective of role or grade. All staff have a legal and professional obligation to act in accordance with this policy.

NHS organisations may be asked to evidence how they operate a satisfactory health records management regime. There are a range of sanctions available if satisfactory arrangements are not in place that vary in severity for both organisation and the individual.

Paper case notes guarantee the authenticity of the record but can make it hard to audit access to the record, depending on where this is stored, because paper records do not have automatic audit logs. It is therefore crucial for the creation and movement of paper records is recorded on the electronic patient administration system (PAS) each time it moves location.

Any outpatient clinic, department, ward or office within the Trust where patient case notes reside is set up as a Location on the PAS for each site. Case notes must be tracked to and from these locations by either manual entry or using a barcode reader.

Paper case notes must not be taken off Trust sites other than for an outreach clinic, or with the patient once transferred to a satellite hospital site e.g. Orsett, Braintree. Patients should never be given their case notes to hold or transfer, even if tracked – refer to MSEPO – 20225 Access to Healthcare Records Policy

This document is intended to instruct, advise and guide all Trust employees who have responsibility for, or who deal with patient case notes during the course of their work, or the correct procedure for recording case note movement.
Failure to comply with this this procedure may result in clinical risk if the case notes cannot be located.
Scope
The scope of this document includes:
Case notes of patients treated by the Trust;
Case notes of patients treated on behalf of the Trust in private healthcare settings;
Case notes where there is integration with health services e.g. jointly held records and local health and social care records;
The scope of this document does not include:
Staff records;
Complaints records;
Corporate records
The management of digital records held on clinical systems
Definitions

table_items.text: Legal statute detailing responsibilities on how personal data is used.
Sets out principles for the fair, lawful and transparent use of personal data.

Health Records Centre & Scanning Bureau – a safe haven and official holding unit for all hard copy patient records that are maintained by HRC staff who are responsible for the delivery and collection of patient records for inpatient and outpatient activity.
Legal statute to improve the quality and outcome of health care for patients and to reposition the mode of provision so health service provision becomes more patient-centred and facilitates choice.
NHS Records Management Code of Practice 2020

A guide in relation to the practice of managing records, relevant to organisations working within, or under contract to, the NHS in England. Provides a framework for consistent and effective records management based on established standards.
Third party facility where patient records are stored during their retention period if there is insufficient space on Trust sites.

Once a primary set of case notes becomes too large and it is no longer possible to file documents safely a new case note folder will be opened. Certain contents will always be carried forward into the new folder to ensure continuity and the removed items will be placed in an overflow folder.

Electronic medical record administration system holding information and data about a patient's care: Acute Care Portal (ACP) = All sites Medway = Basildon Lorenzo - Broomfield Medway/Clinical Electronic Document (CED) = Southend
The primary set of paper case notes. Folder colours are: Blue/Green = Basildon Lilac/buff = Broomfield Yellow/blue/grey = Southend

Health and care information related to patients treated in NHS organisations. This may include: Paper notes; Digital files; Photographs, slides and other images; Microfilm; Physical records; Audio or video recordings; Emails; Computerised records; Scanned records; X-rays and imaging reports; Registers e.g. A&E, Theatre and minor operations

A temporary set of case notes is created when the primary set cannot be located after a thorough search has been undertaking, containing a summary of the patients history available from various sources: Orange = Basildon Pink = Broomfield Buff = Southend

Used for filing documents relating to emergency admissions prior to the patient's primary case notes being supplied. Wards hold their own supplies which should remain on the ward and reused. Ward staff are responsible for creating the volume on the PAS and for filing and merging the documents, physically and on the PAS when the primary set has been delivered.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
The Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group is responsible for  monitoring  health  records  management  including  compliance  with  records tracking.

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for health records management ensuring the Trust complies with legislation, guidance and standards relating to clinical record keeping, health records management including the infrastructure required to support the implementation of this document.

Managing Directors have site responsibility for supporting the Chief Executive in ensuring all staff with access to personal clinical information comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to clinical record keeping and health
records management including systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document.

The Senior Information Risk Owner (SIRO) is the accountable officer ensuring there is a culture of protecting and using patient information appropriately and is concerned with the management of all information assets and provide a focal point for managing information risks and incidents.

The Chief Medical Officer has responsibility for ensuring all medical and dental staff with access to personal clinical information comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to health records management.
The Chief Nursing Officer has responsibility for ensuring all nursing, midwifery and ward staff comply with all legislation, guidance and standards relating to health records management.

The Deputy Director for Clinical Coding, Data Quality and Health Records has overall responsibility for the management and development of health records services and ensuring processes comply with the relevant governance initiatives.

Site Health Records Managers are responsible for the day to day management of the health records service including delivering appropriate training, ensuring staff are competent to carry out their designated duties and are fully aware of their personal responsibilities in respect of record keeping and records management. They are also responsible for ensuring policies, procedures and guidelines are kept up to date in line with national policy and for promoting compliance with this policy is such a way as to ensure the easy, appropriate and timely retrieval of patient information.
All staff, whether clinical or administrative who create, receive and use case notes have a responsibility to ensure that they:
Correctly file documents in accordance with the rules printed on the inside cover of the case note folder;
Track every movement of case notes using the appropriate PAS in accordance with this policy;

All staff generating paperwork are responsible for ensuring it has been correctly filed in the case note folder. Inpatient documentation is the responsibility of the ward administration; outpatient documentation is the responsibility of the medical secretary.
Procedure for Medway
Sending and Receiving

5.1.1 Scan or input the hospital number to send or receive records. The date and time will automatically be generated by the tracking system. Location codes must be entered in the ‘From' and ‘To' fields when sending and the ‘Received' field when receipting in.

5.1.2 Check the patient details that are displayed in the grid after each Send and Receive entry to ensure accuracy. If an error is made cancel the movement by right clicking on the patient details and selecting ‘View case note movement' and delete the erroneous tracking. Users who do not have permissions to do this must contact a senior member of the team.
Comment field
5.2.1  Comments must be added to all case notes movement by using the Comment field. Comments should reflect the reason for the case note movement, for example “on investigation shelf”.
Maintain patient case notes

5.3.1  This menu option can be used to fulfil a number of actions, including sending and receiving of records. Select a patient and then right click to display the sub-menu. The options will depend on the permissions granted to each user.
Add case note

5.4.1  For each new case note created, an electronic case note must be created on Medway. This is done using the ‘Maintain Patient Case Notes' menu option. Select a patient, right click on the details line and select ‘Add Case Note'. The correct case note type must be selected e.g. Main, T1, Obstetric.
Reopening destroyed case notes

5.5.1  Any destroyed case note that is being reopened must be opened electronically in Casenote Tracking by the Health Records team. Staff must update the case note indicator field on the Master Patient Index screen appropriate and then track notes as received or sent.
Print documents
5.6.1  Patient demographic labels, barcode labels, and a front sheet can be printed through this option. N.B. documents may also be printed via the patient's homepage.
Mark as lost
5.7.1  Missing case notes can be identified and a temporary set created and tracked until the original is located. This option is only available to Health Records team. The
temporary case notes must be merged in Medway by the Health Records team once missing case notes have been found and the contents of the temporary folder have been filed in the main case notes.
Mark as destroyed

5.8.1  When a case note record is destroyed in accordance with the Health Records Policy (MSEPO – 20234 Health Records Policy) they are identified on Medway via this option. This option is only available to health records staff.
Request records
5.9.1  The Batch Requesting option is used by Medical Secretaries to request multiple sets of case notes.
Add comment
5.10.1 Select a patient then right click on the details line and select ‘Add Comment'.
5.10.2 New comments will override any previous comments where they are displayed in the speech bubble or on the ‘Quick Case Note Status' report. Previous comments are retained and can still be viewed
View comments

5.11.1 All comments can be viewed via the ‘Maintain Patient Case Note' option on the menu. Select a patient, right click and select ‘View Comments'. Records movements can be deleted via this option for those staff with appropriate access levels.
Quick case note status

5.12.1 This is a menu option within case note tracking which allows users to input multiple hospital numbers and then view or print the output. The display/report lists the hospital number, patient name, last location, last comment and last event date. This report is useful for anyone searching for a number of case notes in a variety of locations.
5.12.2 Enter the hospital number in the ‘Patient Search' field, press <Enter> to display the ‘Patient Case Notes' then select the Case note Type of ‘General' and click on ‘Add'.
5.12.3 It is possible to view the patient homepage through this screen. Highlight any patient on the list and their details will be displayed at the top of the screen.
5.12.4 To print the report right click and select ‘Print Grid'. Select ‘Landscape' printing to produce the best report layout.
Loose paperwork

5.13.1 Loose paperwork must not be tracked as this gives the false impression the full record is in that location. Where loose paperwork is tracked in error it must be notified to the health records team to delete the relevant movement.
Send or Receive Input Errors
5.14.1 Where tracking errors have occurred it must be notified to the health records team who will be able to delete the erroneous movement.
Procedure for Lorenzo

Volume management enables the movement of records volumes to be tracked electronically, by patient number, through the Dispatch and Receipt functions in Lorenzo. It allows users to see at all times the precise location of records.
Dispatch Volume
6.2.1 When records are sent from one area to another the sender must track the record using the ‘Dispatch Volume' function under ‘Volume Management'.
6.2.2 Click into the Volume ID box and scan the barcode on the record or enter the patient IDs for all those notes to be sent out to the same location at the same time.
6.2.3 Select ‘Destination Location' and use the drop down lists to find the correct exact location.
6.2.4 Leave the ‘Destination Services Point' and ‘Destination Session' fields blank.
6.2.5 The ‘Dispatch date/time' will automatically default to the current date and time.
6.2.6 Select the correct ‘Dispatch Reason' from the drop down list.
6.2.7 Select the correct ‘Transport Mode' from the drop down list.

6.2.8 Enter information in the ‘Comments' field such as the data, time and clinic code, including the box number the paper record has been placed in, or the name and extension number of the person requesting the record.
6.2.9 Click on ‘Finish'.
Receipt Volume
6.3.1 Select ‘Volume Management' from the access pane.
6.3.2 Select ‘Receive Volume' from the task pane.
6.3.3 Click in the Volume ID box and scan the record's barcode or enter the patient IDs for all the records being receipted.
6.3.4 Amend the ‘Received date and time' and ‘Receiving Location' accordingly.
6.3.5 Enter any comments in the ‘Comments' field, such as which desk, shelf or office the record is located.
6.3.6 Click on ‘Finish'.
Missing Records

6.4.1 If records have been reported as missing the Health Records Centre (HRC) staff will amend the volume status via the ‘Managing a Volume Status' section. The comments must record who reporting the volume as missing and the estimated date and locations of when the records were last seen.
6.4.2 Once the records have been located the HRC staff will update the volume status, as above, and note who and where the record was found, and update the location as necessary.
Paperwork Volumes

6.5.1 Paperwork should only be dispatched and received using paperwork folders. When a request is made for a temporary record to track paperwork, the user much check on Lorenzo first to see if there is a paperwork volume already created. If not, the user will need to create a paperwork volume.
6.5.2 Select ‘Volume Management' in the task pane.
6.5.3 Select ‘Create a volume' in the task pane. N.B. only staff authorised by the Health Records Manager will have access to be able to create volumes.
6.5.4 Enter the patient's ID in the PAS number field.
6.5.5 From ‘Volume Type' select ‘Paperwork' from the drop down list.
6.5.6 From ‘Nature of Volume' select ‘Temporary' from the drop down list.
6.5.7 The ‘Volume Home Location' should be D139Health Records Centre. The ‘Volume Current Location' should be the location of the physical record. The date and time should remain as defaulted.
6.5.8 Click on ‘Finish'.
6.5.9 Dispatching and Receipting of a Paperwork Volume is the same as for the full record volume, as outlined above.
System unavailability

If the relevant PAS system is unavailable to track the movement of records a ‘To Be Tracked' label must be placed in the plastic pocket on the front of the paper records file. Supplies of these are available from the HRC and wards should have supplies in the Contingency Box.
When the PAS becomes available again any person in possession of records with a ‘To Be Tracked' label on must receipt them to their location. The labels can then be removed and kept for future use.
Tracking compliance audits

The HRC will carry out ad hoc inspections of any area holding case notes. The purpose is to monitor Trust compliance to tracking in a rolling programme of audit. The area being audited will not receive prior notification of the inspection.

A print out of records logged to that area will be extracted from the PAS. The auditor will check 10% of records from the list, noting all other records which are located to the area that are not recorded on the PAS list.

The Trust standard is 80% of records found in an area must be correctly and accurately tracked to that location. The results will be reported to the operational management for that area if they fall below the compliance threshold.

If an area fails an audit, it will be re-audited within 3 months of the first audit. This audit will assess 25 of the records tracked to that location. If the area fails the second audit the area will be audited again within 1 month. This audit will assess 50% of the records tracked to that location. The audit findings will be reported to the Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group and action plans will be developed and agreed for non-compliant users.
Training requirements

All users of health records will be trained on the use of the relevant site PAS. Those who require additional access to create and merge volumes will be provided with specific training by the health records management.
All HRC staff will receive full training during their induction period.
Further training requirements, as identified, can be supported by the HRC management.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group
Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Information Governance & Cyber Security Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Health Records Service of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References
The NHS Records Management Code of Practice 2020 https://www.nhsx.nhs.uk/information-governance/guidance/records-management- code/
